newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine stocks fall on bonds, other markets.
newsitem.headline: Argentine stocks fall on bonds, other markets.

text.p: Argentine stocks fell 0.55 percent Tuesday in cautious, slim dealings in continuation of Monday's session.
Traders said the market fell on slumps in Brady bonds, U.S. stocks and other Latin American bolsas.
Persistent rumors, officially denied at the end of the day, surrounding possible resignations in President Carlos Menem's cabinet added to the declines.
The leading blue-chip Merval stock index closed at 554.33 index points, taking its two-day decline to 2.69 percent.
Trading volumes rose to $17.9 million in the session.
"The market was looking for a floor for the Merval between 540 and 547 points. That level was touched and the market reacted," said Jorge Bonanno, a trader at Interfin.
"The market is agitated by questions surrounding the internal political situation and pressured by possible rises in long U.S. rates," he added.
Another trader said "bonds fell and triggered the depression in the market."
"The market is very erratic and speculative and is not very conducive to long-term investment," said the trader.
According to traders, the market is set to be volatile in coming sessions with a likely ceiling of between 560 and 565 for the Merval.
